title: Survival
subtitle: Get in, type, save, and get out alive

content.text: Chapter 2 — Survival
Get in, type, save, and get out alive. After this chapter, you can use Vim without panicking.
2.1 Opening and Closing Files
To open a file, type {key:nvim} followed by a filename at your terminal prompt:
If the file exists, you see its contents. If it doesn't exist, you get an empty buffer — Vim creates the file when you save.

content.caption: Neovim showing hello.py — file content above, status bar at the bottom

content.text: You can also type just {key:nvim} with no filename to open an empty scratch buffer. Or use {key:vim} or even {key:vi} — on most systems, they all launch the same editor.
Saving — {key::}{key:w}
Press {key::} to open the command line at the bottom of the screen, type {key:w} (for "write"), and press {key:Enter}. Your file is saved.

content.caption: After :w — the status bar confirms the file was written

content.text: Quitting — {key::}{key:q}
The most famous question in programming: "How do I quit Vim?" Press {key::}, type {key:q} (for "quit"), press {key:Enter}.
If you have unsaved changes, Vim won't let you quit with {key::}{key:q}. You have three options:
Pick one save-and-quit combo and make it a habit. {key:Z}{key:Z} is the fastest — two keystrokes, no colon, no Enter.
2.2 Insert Mode and Back Again
Right now, you're in normal mode. Every key is a command. You can't type text — pressing {key:j} moves the cursor down instead of typing the letter 'j'. This is the part that surprises everyone.
To type text, press {key:i} to enter insert mode. The status bar at the bottom will show {key:INSERT}. Now keys type text, just like any other editor.

content.caption: Insert mode — notice INSERT at the bottom. Keys now type text.

content.text: When you're done typing, press {key:Esc} to return to normal mode. The {key:INSERT} indicator disappears. You're back to command mode.

content.caption: After pressing Escape — INSERT is gone, we're back in normal mode

content.text: That's the fundamental rhythm of Vim editing: {key:i} to insert, type what you need, {key:Esc} to return. Get in, type, get out.
2.3 The Escape Habit

This is the single most important habit in Vim: after every edit, press {key:Esc}. After typing a line of code, {key:Esc}. After fixing a typo, {key:Esc}. After pasting text, {key:Esc}. Always return to normal mode.
Normal mode is your home base. It's called "normal" for a reason — it's the mode you should normally be in. Insert mode is a brief excursion: get in, type, get out.

New Vim users stay in insert mode too long. They type a paragraph, then try to navigate with arrow keys, then get confused when they can't use {key:d}{key:d} to delete a line. The fix is simple: build the {key:Esc} reflex now. It will save you from every Vim confusion.
If you ever feel lost or stuck, press {key:Esc} a few times. You'll end up in normal mode, and from there you can do anything.
2.4 Undo and Redo
Vim is safe to experiment in. Made a mistake? Press {key:u} to undo. Keep pressing {key:u} to undo more. Vim supports multi-level undo — you can undo all the way back to the original file.
Went too far? Press {key:Ctrl-R} to redo — bring your changes back.

content.caption: After pressing u — the deleted line is restored

content.text: A "change" in Vim is everything between entering and leaving insert mode. If you press {key:i}, type three lines, then press {key:Esc}, a single {key:u} undoes all three lines. This is why the Escape habit matters — it creates natural undo checkpoints.

Vim's undo is actually a tree, not a stack. Every branch is preserved. We'll explore the undo tree in detail in Chapter 27, but for now, just know that {key:u} and {key:Ctrl-R} will always keep you safe.
2.5 Basic Movement: {key:h} {key:j} {key:k} {key:l}
In normal mode, move the cursor with four keys right on the home row:

content.caption: Cursor moved to row 3, column 6 using j and l — hands never left the home row

content.text: Yes, the arrow keys work too. But they defeat the purpose. The whole point of Vim is that your hands never leave the home row. Every time you reach for an arrow key, you lose a fraction of a second. Over thousands of edits per day, that adds up.

Why {key:h}{key:j}{key:k}{key:l}? On the ADM-3A terminal where vi was born in 1976, these keys had arrow symbols printed on them. It's a historical accident that turned into the most ergonomic cursor movement in computing.
Don't try to memorize all four keys at once. Start with {key:j} (down) and {key:k} (up) — they're the ones you'll use most. {key:h} and {key:l} will come naturally.

content.caption: Navigating with h j k l
